He made his debut with Ospreys in 2007 and is committed to representing his country, Wales.

Two men were stopped by US border agents near Sumas, Washington, on Tuesday, with one of them firing a weapon and fleeing. The incident led to the arrest of four individuals involved in a drug smuggling operation from Canada to San Francisco. The men were carrying backpacks containing a large quantity of MDMA (ecstasy), and a third man, a Canadian citizen, was arrested in British Columbia. A woman and her boyfriend were also arrested for their involvement in the plan. The area is known for smuggling activities, and the defendants face conspiracy and drug-related charges.

The NSPCC's Childline service has seen a significant increase in the number of children seeking help for online abuse and cyberbullying, with over 4,500 cases in the past year. The charity emphasizes the severe impact of online trolls on children's mental health and well-being, with some as young as seven experiencing torment and fear. Dame Esther Rantzen highlights the need for adult intervention and school involvement to address this growing issue. The report, released during Anti-Bullying Week, also includes advice from young people on coping with bullying.

The US's decision to abstain from vetoing a UN resolution condemning Israeli settlements has caused tension between the two allies. The resolution, which passed on Friday, calls for an end to settlement construction, considering it illegal under international law. This move angered Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who accused the US of drafting and pushing for the resolution. In response, Netanyahu summoned US and UN ambassadors, recalled Israeli ambassadors, and took other diplomatic actions. The Jerusalem Planning Committee postponed a vote on new settlement homes, citing a request from Netanyahu's office to avoid further conflict with the US ahead of Secretary of State John Kerry's speech on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. Kerry is expected to address the Israeli government's criticism of the Obama administration and present his vision for peace. Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas sees the resolution as a positive step towards the upcoming Middle East peace conference in France.

The passage describes the celebrations and tributes for Queen Elizabeth II's 90th birthday, including a BBC interview with Prince William praising the Queen's dedication to duty and service. The Queen's visit to Windsor's Royal Mail delivery office and the release of commemorative stamps featuring the Royal Family are highlighted. The text also mentions the criticism Prince William has faced regarding his royal duties and his response to it, as well as the plans for the Queen's birthday celebrations and the ongoing debate about the media's coverage of the royal family.

West Ham United, a Premier League team, defeated Cheltenham Town from League Two 2-0 in the EFL Cup. Diafra Sakho and Andre Ayew scored quick goals before halftime, securing the win. Cheltenham had some chances but couldn't convert, and West Ham could've increased their lead if not for a goal-line clearance and a good save. The result eliminated League Two's presence in the competition before the third-round draw.

Aidan McNicholl, a 36-year-old hospital radiographer, was killed in a motorcycle collision on the A5 at Cerrigydrudion on Sunday. The driver, Andreas Werner, failed to see McNicholl and turned his vehicle, causing the fatal crash. Werner pleaded guilty to careless driving and was fined and banned from driving in the UK for two years. The victim's family did not wish for Werner to be imprisoned, acknowledging it was a momentary lapse in judgement.

Imran Khawaja, a British jihadist who gained notoriety in Syria through online propaganda, returned to the UK and was arrested. He was a member of Rayat al Tawheed, an Islamic State-affiliated group known for sophisticated recruitment tactics targeting young British Muslims. Khawaja's activities in Syria included creating propaganda, soliciting donations, and participating in violent acts, as evidenced by a gruesome photo. He attempted to re-enter the UK secretly, but was arrested and faces life imprisonment. The police consider him highly dangerous, and his motives for returning remain unclear.

Kayden Jackson, a 22-year-old forward, has joined Barnsley from Wrexham, where he scored four goals in 36 appearances last season. Barnsley's caretaker manager, Paul Heckingbottom, praised Jackson's pace and ability to trouble defenders, which aligns with the team's playing style. This transfer marks Barnsley's third signing for the upcoming season, announced ahead of their League One play-off final at Wembley.

Numerous bottles of detergent, believed to be from a lost shipping container, have washed up on beaches in Cornwall, UK. The National Trust and other organisations are working to clear the bottles, which may pose a risk to wildlife. While the source of the bottles is suspected to be from a known lost container of 'Vanish' detergent, there is currently no concrete evidence to confirm this.

A crash on the A9 in Caithness resulted in one person being taken to hospital with serious injuries and several others sustaining minor injuries. The incident led to a road closure, with diversions via the A897 Helmsdale to Melvich route. Police Scotland is investigating the incident.

Dorian Dervite, a 28-year-old French centre-back, has signed a new contract with Bolton Wanderers after helping the club secure promotion to the Championship. Dervite made 14 appearances last season and has been a consistent performer since joining Bolton in 2014, making 83 appearances in total. His contract renewal follows those of several other key players, ensuring a strong squad for the upcoming Championship campaign.

The Liberal Democrats and Labour have a history of forming alliances to challenge the government on various issues, including Brexit and other legislative matters. However, tensions arose when the Lib Dems insisted on amendments regarding EU citizens' rights and parliamentary approval for Brexit, while Labour deferred to the Commons. The Lib Dems accused Labour of conceding to the government and building false hope, while Labour criticised the Lib Dems for grandstanding and creating campaign material. Despite these differences, both parties expressed a willingness to continue working together on shared issues, albeit with some residual tensions.

The passage discusses the low priority given to defence in the UK's political landscape, despite growing global instability. The UK's military interventions and public fatigue contribute to this trend. The article highlights the reduced defence spending and military capabilities, with potential consequences for NATO relations and US perceptions. It mentions the upcoming election's lack of focus on defence, with parties offering limited details. The text also covers the debate around nuclear deterrence, with varying party stances, and the challenges of maintaining a credible military force.

Barcelona has made a voluntary tax payment of â¬13.5 million regarding the signing of Neymar, despite denying any tax-related crime. This payment was made to cover potential interpretations of the contracts involved in the transfer, which has been under investigation. The club initially paid Â£48.6 million for Neymar, but the total cost, including various fees, is estimated at Â£106.8 million. The investigation follows the resignation of former president Sandro Rosell, who is also being investigated for alleged misappropriation of funds.

Michael Luciw, a 27-year-old passenger in a van, was killed in a collision with a car driven by Albert Newman, who was driving the wrong way on the motorway. Mr. Luciw's family advocates for regular driving tests for retired individuals, citing concerns about their driving abilities. The family mourns Mr. Luciw's tragic death, emphasizing his young age and the loss of future milestones with his baby daughter. They believe stricter driving assessments for older drivers could prevent similar accidents. The van driver, Andy Harrington, also supports medical examinations for retired drivers. Currently, UK drivers over 70 renew their licenses every three years with a self-assessment form, but no medical or driving test is required. The DVLA maintains that evidence does not indicate older drivers are more prone to causing serious accidents and that they have procedures to remove driving entitlement for those with medical conditions. Age UK emphasizes the importance of supporting older drivers to maintain their independence.

A group of women who suffered severe side effects from transvaginal mesh implants have raised concerns about the safety of the procedure. An independent review was conducted, but two patient representatives on the review panel resigned due to disagreements with the final report, which they believed was watered down. Professor Alison Britton will now examine the review process and its conclusions. The report recommended against routine use of the implants for pelvic organ prolapse and emphasized the need for informed consent and mandatory adverse event reporting. Despite calls for a ban, the health secretary stated that the government does not have the authority to do so, as it falls under the jurisdiction of the UK regulatory body. The chairwoman of the review, Tracey Gillies, apologized for not reaching a consensus among panel members and faced criticism from affected women. Two other patient representatives and a consultant also resigned due to dissatisfaction with the final report. Over 20,000 Scottish women have received mesh or tape implants, and more than 400 are taking legal action due to complications.

Laura Muir, aged 23, broke Liz McColgan's 25-year-old 5K record by 14 seconds with a time of 14 minutes and 49.12 seconds. McColgan initially questioned the validity of the record due to the nature of the race, as Muir was the only competitor in the 5K event, but British Athletics confirmed that the time is expected to be ratified as an official record. McColgan praised Muir's talent, suggesting she has the potential to win world medals and improve her 5K time even further.

Jung, riding Sam, won the competition, with Astier Nicolas and Phillip Dutton claiming silver and bronze respectively. Great Britain's William Fox-Pitt, a three-time Olympic medallist, finished 12th despite a strong show-jumping performance, due to time penalties in the cross-country phase. The article also promotes fan engagement with equestrian sports during the Rio Olympics, offering a guide and newsletter subscription.

Andy Murray, a 30-year-old British tennis player, defeated Fabio Fognini in a tense and dramatic match at Wimbledon, securing a spot in the fourth round. The match lasted over two hours, with Murray winning in four sets. Fognini, the 29th seed, had opportunities to force a fifth set but Murray's resilience and a late surge secured the victory. The match was characterized by Fognini's fluctuating performance, an ankle injury, and on-court tensions. Murray will next face Benoit Paire, while fellow Briton Johanna Konta also advanced to the second week.

Paramedics and police were called to Joe's Bar in Dungiven following a sudden death, where they found evidence of alcohol being served outside of licensing hours. The license holder, Colleen O'Neill, and James Thomas were charged with allowing the consumption of liquor outside of permitted hours. The court heard that licensing laws in Dungiven were not always followed, and the judge expressed concern over Ms O'Neill's previous record, fining her Â£3,000 and ordering the bar's closure for three months.

Mike Nesbitt, leader of the Ulster Unionists, stated that the election should be a referendum on the handling of the Renewable Heat Incentive issue. However, his comments suggesting voters support other parties have shifted the focus onto his own party. Nesbitt defended his remarks, emphasizing the importance of partnership and expressing his preference for a coalition with the SDLP over Sinn FÃ©in. The party's manifesto, 'Real Partnership', covers various issues, including healthcare, policing, infrastructure, and LGBT rights, while also advocating for a 'Cleaning Up Stormont' initiative to address corruption.

The Justice Minister of Northern Ireland, Claire Sugden, has confirmed plans to introduce a motion for automatic pardons for gay and bisexual men convicted of historical sexual offences. This move mirrors recent proposals in England and Wales, known as 'Turing's Law', which aims to posthumously pardon those convicted of now-abolished sexual crimes and allow living individuals to apply for pardons. The minister has secured executive agreement and will seek legislative consent from the assembly to ensure equal treatment for gay and bisexual men in Northern Ireland. The motion will provide an opportunity for the criminal justice system to rectify past injustices.

Laura Muir, a 23-year-old from Kinross, Scotland, achieved an impressive second-place finish in a 1500m race, setting a new Scottish record. Her time of 4:19.12 surpassed Yvonne Murray's previous record and placed her second on the British all-time list. Muir, who also holds the Scottish mile record, expressed her excitement about the result, especially as it was her first race of the season at this distance. She aims to secure an Olympic spot for Great Britain at the upcoming British trials in Birmingham. Muir's recent success includes an 800m win in France and a focus on training while pursuing veterinary studies.
A collection of images showcases the pristine water quality of 26 beaches in Scotland, which have been ranked as the country's best.

A Met Police barrister, Richard Horwell QC, argued that the Russian state was likely behind the plot to kill Alexander Litvinenko, a former KGB officer who defected to the UK. Mr. Litvinenko was poisoned with a fatal dose of radioactive polonium-210 during a meeting with two suspects, Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi, in London in 2006. The use of polonium indicates some level of Russian state involvement, according to Mr. Horwell. He emphasized that this does not directly implicate Russian President Vladimir Putin, but rather suggests a broader state-sponsored motive. The suspects left a trail of polonium and have not provided credible explanations, but attempts to extradite them from Russia have failed.

Steve Smith, aged 26, has been appointed as the new captain of the Australian cricket team for both the one-day and Twenty20 formats, replacing the retired Michael Clarke. Smith, who has previously captained the Test side against India, is praised for his talent and leadership skills. David Warner, 28, has been named as vice-captain, despite past disciplinary issues, as selectors believe he has matured and will embrace the leadership role. The new leadership duo will take charge after the final Ashes Test against England.

A political leader, Mr Farron, has expressed his support for LGBT+ rights and equal marriage, despite previously voting against an Equality Bill in 2007. He refused to answer questions about his personal beliefs on homosexual sex, but emphasized his commitment to defending and extending LGBT+ rights, particularly for transgender individuals who face marriage inequality due to the spousal veto.

Accord Healthcare is set to reopen a former Sanofi drug manufacturing site in Fawdon, aiming to employ many ex-Sanofi staff. This move is expected to bring significant economic benefits to the region, with the potential for highly skilled job opportunities and long-term investment. Accord Healthcare has a global presence, producing and distributing a wide range of pharmaceutical products to numerous countries.

The local council is experiencing a significant turnover in its senior leadership. Richard Ellis, the former interim director of corporate governance and acting deputy chief executive, is leaving at the end of his contract. Ciaran Monaghan, head of the chief executive's office, and Ewan Sutherland, head of human resources and customer services, are departing through a voluntary redundancy and early retirement scheme. This turnover highlights the council's struggle to retain key personnel, as noted by the opposition leader, Stephen Flynn, who anticipates more departures soon.

Michael Martin, an English rider, experienced a crash at the TT and faced issues with his Fireblade bike. He initially announced his retirement from road racing but later clarified that he is not quitting racing entirely. Martin skipped the North West 200 due to his teammate's crash and will not participate in the upcoming Ulster Grand Prix, citing the bike's lack of competitiveness. He expresses his desire to focus on classic and unique racing events.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) secured a significant victory in the recent elections, winning the majority of governor posts and the presidential election. This marks a substantial defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP), which has dominated Nigerian politics since 1999. The PDP's decline is evident in its loss of key northern states and its failure to secure victories in the oil-producing states. The APC's success relegates the PDP to a regional party, primarily in the south-east and Niger Delta. The elections were marred by violence and ethnic tensions in some areas, but overall, Nigeria's democracy appears to be maturing with a peaceful transition of power. The PDP's loss can be attributed to various factors, including corruption allegations, defections, and its inability to address the Islamist insurgency in the north-east.

An environmental group, Mighty, has accused the agricultural commodities trader Olam and its main stakeholder, Temasek, of being linked to unsustainable palm oil practices in Indonesia, which contribute to the annual haze affecting Southeast Asian countries. Mighty's report claims that Olam creates a market for palm oil from unknown sources, potentially encouraging rogue traders. Olam denies these allegations, stating they have strict sourcing policies against burning and deforestation. The company has a small market share and buys mostly from third-party suppliers, making supplier policing challenging. Temasek, as Olam's majority stakeholder, could be indirectly connected to these practices. The palm oil industry is massive and often criticized for labour issues and environmental damage, with debates between green groups and executives on responsibility. Mighty also criticizes Olam's operations in Gabon, accusing them of deforestation, while Olam defends its sustainable practices and transparency.
A restaurant has started serving puppy platters following a new law permitting dogs to dine at restaurants, provided they are seated outdoors.

Fernando Forestieri's knee injury has limited his playing time, while David Nugent may return from a groin issue. Jacob Butterfield seeks a starting role after scoring as a substitute in the previous match.

The Pakistan government has lifted a ban on YouTube, which was imposed in 2012 due to the controversial film 'Innocence of Muslims'. The Pakistan Telecommunication Authority (PTA) directed internet service providers to open access, as Google launched a Pakistan-specific version of YouTube. Google has provided a process for the PTA to request the blocking of offensive content. However, YouTube stated that government requests for content removal would not be automatically granted and would be reviewed according to community guidelines. Some activists are calling for transparency regarding the deal between Google and the government.

Domenico Scala, the head of FIFA's Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, is facing a potential conflict of interest in the upcoming FIFA presidential election due to his shared nationality with one of the candidates, Gianni Infantino. Musa Bility, the LFA boss, has threatened to take the matter to the Court of Arbitration for Sport if Scala does not withdraw by Thursday. Scala's spokesperson argues that there is no conflict of interest as there is no incumbent president among the five candidates. The election is scheduled for February 26th, and Bility has demanded an explanation from the committee regarding the lack of adherence to previous election protocols.

Two men, Daniel Timbers and Barry Joy, were killed in a workplace incident at Harford Attachments, a company that manufactures digger buckets. The incident occurred in a paint-spraying area and was likely caused by a flashover explosion due to a build-up of toxic fumes and subsequent ignition, resulting in a fireball. Forensic investigations and witness statements are being collected, and the Health and Safety Executive is involved in gathering evidence, including input from electrical safety specialists.

Morocco and Tunisia have both faced disciplinary action from the Confederation of African Football (Caf) but will now participate in the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations. Morocco was initially banned from the competition after refusing to host the 2015 tournament due to Ebola fears, but this decision was overturned by the Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas). Tunisia, meanwhile, was ordered to apologise to Caf for complaints regarding refereeing decisions during the 2015 Nations Cup, which they did, thus avoiding expulsion. Both nations are now looking forward to the 2017 tournament, with Tunisia aiming to extend their record of consecutive appearances.

A mass fracas occurred in the 95th minute of a football match between Manchester City and Chelsea, resulting in red cards for City's Sergio Aguero and Fernandinho. Aguero received a four-match ban for violent conduct, while Fernandinho got a three-match ban for his involvement. Chelsea's Cesc Fabregas will face no further action. Pep Guardiola, City's manager, apologised for his team's behaviour. Both clubs must respond to the charge by 8 December.

Mae gan Gymru gyfraddau goresgyn canser isel, ac mae cynllun peilot newydd yn cael ei gynnal yng Nghwm Cynon a Chastell-nedd i wella'r sefyllfa. Mae'r gobaith yn cael diagnosis cynt ac yn welli cyflymder y broses, gan gynnig cymorth i gleifion a meddygon teulu.

England dominated the second Test against Pakistan at Old Trafford, winning by a significant margin and levelling the series. Joe Root was the standout performer, scoring a double century and a quickfire unbeaten half-century, earning him the man of the match award. Root's performance, along with England's overall dominance in batting and bowling, impressed former England players like Michael Vaughan and Geoffrey Boycott. Pakistan's struggles with batting consistency and confidence were evident, with only two players crossing the 50-run mark in the series so far. The third Test is scheduled for Edgbaston, with Vaughan predicting a tightly contested series.

Warren Gatland, the head coach of the British and Irish Lions, has selected his backroom team for the New Zealand tour, including interim coach Rob Howley and forwards coach McBryde, who will act as head coach. McBryde, having led Wales on previous tours, is honoured to represent his country again. The Welsh Rugby Union will appoint assistant coaches for the summer tour, with announcements expected soon. The involvement of Welsh coaches in the Lions tour is seen as a valuable opportunity for their development and a benefit to Welsh rugby as a whole, according to WRU chairman Gareth Davies.

Charlie Austin's early penalty put Southampton in control against Hull City, who lost two starting strikers to injury in the first half. Hull fought back in the second half, with Robert Snodgrass scoring and assisting Michael Dawson's header. Despite Southampton's late pressure, Hull held on for a 2-1 win, ending a six-game losing streak. The result was significant for both teams, with Southampton coming off a famous European win and Hull battling injuries and a poor run of form.

A motorcyclist was killed in a collision with a tractor on the B1191 at Thornton, near Woodhall Spa. The incident occurred around 14:15 BST, and the police have requested witnesses to come forward. The road was temporarily closed in both directions between Woodhall Spa and Horncastle.

President Ivanov of Macedonia cancelled an investigation into alleged abuse of power by politicians, citing the need to defend national interests and end the country's turmoil. This decision was met with criticism from the opposition leader, Zoran Zaev, who called the move illegal and urged protests, as well as from EU officials who stated that it contradicted the rule of law and jeopardised Macedonia's EU membership aspirations. The crisis began with the release of covert recordings suggesting ministerial corruption, vote-rigging, and murder cover-ups. Zaev has been publicly releasing recordings since 2015, alleging widespread government corruption, while the government denies the charges and accuses Zaev of destabilisation attempts.

Swansea City, facing a managerial change after Bob Bradley's sacking, will be led by Curtis and Paul Williams against Bournemouth. The club aims to appoint a new manager soon, with Paul Clement as the top choice. Swansea's recent struggles are attributed to frequent managerial changes and the loss of key players, deviating from their successful 'Swansea Way'. Despite challenges, Curtis believes in the squad's ability to avoid relegation and emphasizes the club's remarkable journey from near-bankruptcy to Premier League promotion.

The passage describes a crucial football match between Dagenham & Redbridge (The Daggers) and Leyton Orient (The O's) with significant implications for both teams. Dagenham, facing relegation, needed a win to maintain their League Two status, while Orient aimed to secure a play-off spot. The game saw a thrilling comeback from Dagenham, who initially conceded two goals but fought back to level the score. However, Armand Gnanduillet's winner for Orient sealed Dagenham's fate, relegating them to the National League. This result highlights Dagenham's struggles throughout the season, with a poor goal difference and a less productive attack compared to previous years. Despite the setback, Dagenham's manager, John Still, expressed his commitment to leading the team back to promotion next season. Meanwhile, Orient's interim manager, Andy Hessenthaler, acknowledged the challenges of losing two managers in a season but emphasized the team's professionalism and dedication to winning for their fans.

Steven Gerrard, the former Liverpool captain and ex-England international, will return to Liverpool as a youth coach in February, marking his first role since retiring as a player. This appointment is welcomed by Liverpool manager Jurgen Klopp, who revealed Gerrard's aspirations to become a manager in the future. Gerrard, who had a successful playing career at Liverpool and in the MLS, is currently working towards his UEFA A coaching license, a requirement for managing in the Premier League. He was previously linked with the managerial position at MK Dons but felt it was too soon for him.
Morton defeated Alloa in a football match with a final score of 4-1. McManus and Johnstone scored two goals each for Morton, while McAusland scored Alloa's only goal.

In Birmingham, Ofsted uncovered children being educated in unsanitary conditions at three now-closed locations. Sir Michael Wilshaw, Chief Inspector of Schools in England, expressed concern that these cases are likely just the beginning, with children at risk of abuse or radicalisation. The investigation has focused on 18 unregulated schools, primarily in Muslim communities in the Midlands. While some part-time education centres operate legally, Ofsted and ministers worry that some are exploiting home education rights to run illegal schools. Sir Michael criticised officials for giving confusing advice to proprietors of the closed schools. The government has funded a team of inspectors to investigate illegal schools, emphasising that any religious group operating in unsafe and unhygienic conditions will be targeted. The Education Secretary has consented to prosecutions, and a consultation on further regulation is ongoing until mid-January.

Lilliard Gin is a small-scale distillery located in Jedburgh, aiming to showcase the local flavours and terroir of the Scottish Borders. It is the first gin distillery in the region and complements the existing Scottish Borders Brewery. The lead distiller, Kate Macinnes, is excited about the potential for the area to become a distilling hub, with several whisky distillery proposals in the planning stages. The gin's name honours a local legend, Lilliard, a female warrior from the Battle of Ancrum Moor, reflecting the distillery's connection to the region and its female production team.

Harry Whitlam was killed in August 2013 when Gary Green, who was heavily intoxicated, reversed a tractor into him at Swithens Farm. Green was more than twice the legal driving limit, having consumed the equivalent of 13 pints of beer. The incident occurred on private land, leading to prosecution under health and safety laws. Green's behaviour was described as reckless by the Health and Safety Executive, and he was sentenced to 16 months and two weeks in jail. Harry's mother, Pam Whitlam, expressed her family's grief and emphasized the impact of the tragedy, hoping to remember Harry's life beyond the day of the accident.

Luis Suarez, a 27-year-old Uruguayan striker, has had his appeal against a four-month ban for biting Italy's Giorgio Chiellini partially upheld by the Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas). While Suarez is still banned from playing in competitive matches, he is now allowed to train with his new club Barcelona, participate in friendly matches, and engage in football-related activities. The full explanation for this ruling will be published later. Suarez's legal team argued that the initial ban by FIFA was excessive and disproportionate, and while Cas agreed that preventing him from training was excessive, they largely upheld the original sanctions. Suarez will miss the remaining eight games of his nine-match international ban and is set to make his competitive Barcelona debut in El Clasico against Real Madrid on October 26th. The decision has sparked mixed reactions, with some praising the proportionality of the ruling, while the world players' union Fifpro expressed disappointment that the sanctions were not significantly reduced.

Richard Blake-Smith and his partner Anna won a race by beating Vytautas Kirkliauskas of Lithuania. The race involved carrying a partner over a 380-metre course with various obstacles. The winners will now compete at the World Championships in Finland.

The UK government's plan to replace the paper tax disc system with an electronic one has raised concerns about job security for employees at the DVLA. In a letter to Swansea East AM Mike Hedges, Minister Stephen Hammond addressed these concerns, stating that while job roles may change and some tasks may decrease, the government aims to manage any reductions through redeployment rather than redundancies. Mr Hedges welcomed this assurance, highlighting the benefits of the new system while acknowledging the potential impact on job opportunities at the DVLA.

The EU is pressuring Hungary to withdraw three laws that have been criticised for their potential impact on human rights and academic freedom. These laws include tight controls on asylum seekers, non-governmental organisations (NGOs), and a higher education law that could lead to the closure of the Central European University, founded by George Soros. Hungary's government, led by Prime Minister Viktor Orban, has refused to back down, stating that these are domestic issues and that Poland has vowed to veto any EU sanctions. The EU's ability to strip Hungary of its voting rights is complicated by the requirement for unanimous approval from member countries. The situation has sparked protests in Hungary and concerns from human rights groups.

Emma Watson will star as Belle in the live-action remake of Beauty and the Beast, alongside Dan Stevens as the Beast, Kevin Kline as Belle's father Maurice, and Emma Thompson as Mrs. Potts. The film, directed by Bill Condon, will also feature Luke Evans as Gaston, Josh Gad as LeFou, and will be released in US cinemas in March 2017.

Adrian Gill, a renowned columnist and author, passed away after a battle with cancer. Known for his witty and fearless writing style, Gill was a prominent figure at the Sunday Times, where he worked for over two decades. Despite his illness, Gill maintained a positive outlook, expressing gratitude for his life experiences. His final column, reflecting on his diagnosis, will be published posthumously. Tributes poured in from colleagues and peers, praising Gill's exceptional writing talent, compassion, and unique personality.

Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar, a Mongolian rapper, was allegedly attacked during a performance in Ulan Bator, where he wore a traditional Mongolian robe with a swastika symbol. Russian news reports claimed he was assaulted with a bottle and kicked. The rapper's father confirmed the attack, stating his son was in a coma for 10 days with severe brain injuries. The swastika, an ancient symbol in Mongolia, predates its association with the Nazis. The Russian embassy is investigating but disputes local reports, while the alleged attacker, a Russian diplomat, has not been arrested, with police citing the non-serious nature of the injuries.

Campaigners from Plane Stupid protested against airport expansion, trespassing on the northern runway. They were charged with aggravated trespass and entering a restricted area. The police will review airport security and the campaigners will appear in court on August 19th.

Glamorgan's innings was anchored by Nick Selman's century, his second in first-class cricket, as seam bowlers Matt Taylor and Craig Miles took regular wickets. Selman's form returned after a string of low scores, while Aneurin Donald provided quick runs. Gloucestershire's bowlers struggled, and their batsmen faced a challenging task in gloomy conditions, ending the day evenly poised. Michael Hogan leads Glamorgan in Jacques Rudolph's absence. Selman expressed satisfaction with his innings, while Taylor was pleased with his bowling performance and the opportunity to play with the red ball.

Craig Hughes, a 33-year-old man from Flint, was arrested for making online threats to commit a murder. He confessed to planning to lure police officers to a fake crime scene and then shoot them. Hughes made these threats while intoxicated and had a prior conviction for firearm possession. Despite his legal team's claims that he had no intention of harming himself or others, the court took the threats seriously, especially as Hughes was on bail for unrelated firearms charges at the time. He will be sentenced for his crimes next week.

The match saw a strong performance from Surrey, who posted an impressive score of 255-7 after an early setback, thanks to a crucial partnership between Davies and Foakes. Yorkshire's run-chase was hindered by Stuart Meaker's three-wicket burst, which included key wickets. Despite a fighting effort from Tim Bresnan and Matthew Waite, Yorkshire fell short, all out for 236. Surrey's captain, Gareth Batty, praised his team's performance, highlighting the impact of the Davies-Foakes partnership. Yorkshire's captain, Alex Lees, expressed disappointment, acknowledging their bowlers' efforts but lamenting the lack of substantial contributions from their top-order batters.

The crew of a converted trawler radioed for help as they were taking on water. The coastguards responded, and with the assistance of the RNLI lifeboat crew, they installed a pump and towed the vessel to safety.

Laura Muir, a 24-year-old Scottish middle-distance runner, will miss the 2018 Commonwealth Games on Australia's Gold Coast due to her veterinary medicine exams in May. Despite her disappointment, she prioritises completing her degree. Muir reflects on her recent success at the World Athletics Championships, finishing fourth and sixth in the 1500m and 5,000m, respectively, and achieving a new outdoor personal best. She expresses optimism for her future in running, considering the World Indoor Championships in March and the potential for multiple Olympic appearances.

Robbie Savage discusses Liverpool's current struggles and their chances of repeating last season's title challenge. He highlights the impact of losing key players like Luis Suarez and Daniel Sturridge, and criticizes Brendan Rodgers' transfer decisions, particularly in the forward positions. Savage also analyzes Liverpool's defensive weaknesses and the challenges Steven Gerrard faces in extending his career. The article previews the upcoming match against Chelsea, suggesting Liverpool's tactics and lineup, but acknowledges the difficulty of beating a superior Chelsea side.

A new Â£45 million facility in Kilmarnock will be named after the late writer William McIlvanney. The campus will include schools, a Gaelic school, and a childcare centre. McIlvanney, a renowned author, journalist, and broadcaster, was known for his contributions to Scottish literature and culture. He was born and educated in Kilmarnock and later became an English teacher before pursuing writing full-time. His works, including the Laidlaw trilogy and other Glasgow-based novels, earned him critical acclaim and the title "Godfather of Tartan Noir".

A sea mine, believed to be a British relic from the 1940s or 1950s, was discovered near the town of Gourock, prompting a precautionary evacuation of three streets and an exclusion zone on the river and at sea. Experts from the Royal Navy are working to secure the mine, but its deteriorated state makes it challenging to determine the amount of explosive material it holds. The operation caused temporary disruptions to ferry services and sailing activities in the area.

The UK government and National Lottery have committed funding for 31 Olympic and Paralympic sports, totalling Â£345 million, with the aim of maintaining Britain's success at the Tokyo 2020 Games. This is a slight decrease from the previous funding allocation for Rio. Cycling, despite its strong medal performance in Rio, has seen a funding cut. Badminton, however, has had its funding removed entirely, despite winning a medal in Rio, with its representatives expressing shock and disappointment. UK Sport justifies the funding decisions by prioritizing sports with higher medal potential, while acknowledging the need to invest in a broader range of sports for future success.

Three Victorian hotels in a designated conservation area in Bournemouth will be demolished to make way for a large-scale development, including a new hotel and assisted-living apartments. Despite strong objections from English Heritage and local residents regarding the conservation area's preservation, the planning board approved the project, citing tourism and improved living for older residents as benefits. The development will result in the loss of historic buildings and trees, but supporters argue that it is necessary for the area's progress.

A 20-year-old soldier, Pte Matthew Boyd, was killed in a brutal attack during a night out in Brecon. Jake Vallely, aged 24, was found guilty of the murder, while his friend Aaeron Evans was cleared of any involvement. The incident, which occurred outside a bar, was captured on CCTV, showing Vallely punching and beating Pte Boyd until he was unconscious. The attack has shocked the community, with police pleading for people to avoid violence during nights out. Pte Boyd, described as a loving and caring individual with a promising career, was originally from Northern Ireland and was in Brecon for military training. The soldier's family paid tribute, expressing their grief and highlighting the support they received from the local community.

Andrew Travers, the Chief Executive of Barnet Council, stepped down following a significant error during the EU Referendum where voters were turned away due to missing names on the poll list. An independent investigation has been launched to review the incident and the appropriateness of the council's electoral arrangements. The investigation's findings will be made public, and temporary leadership arrangements are in place while a long-term replacement is found. Voters expressed concerns about the fairness of the election results due to the initial issues.

The football match between Gateshead and Wrexham ended 2-1 to the home side. Gateshead took the lead through a Josh Gillies free-kick, but Wrexham equalised before half-time with a Sean Newton set-piece. The second half saw Gateshead dominate and they scored the winner through Ryan Bowman's header. The Gateshead manager praised his team's performance, especially in the second half, while the Wrexham manager was disappointed with their display after the break.
The Global AgeWatch Index 2014 ranks the social and economic well-being of the elderly in 96 countries, with Norway at the top and Afghanistan at the bottom, followed by Mozambique.

A new network of satellites, known as OneWeb, aims to provide global broadband coverage by launching a large constellation of spacecraft. The initial plan includes at least 600 satellites, with the potential to expand to over 2,000. This project requires a significant shift in satellite manufacturing, focusing on high volume and low cost, similar to car and plane production. Airbus, a key partner, has set up assembly lines in Toulouse and Florida, aiming to produce three satellites per shift at a lower cost. The project has raised $1.7 billion in equity and is seeking loans for full rollout. OneWeb aims to set new standards in debris mitigation, ensuring old satellites are de-orbited within two years to reduce space junk. The UK Space Agency will play a crucial role in licensing and regulation, with potential economic benefits for the UK. The success of OneWeb's concept may be influenced by its first-mover advantage, but competition from companies like SpaceX and Boeing is expected.

Mr Swinney, a Scottish government official, criticizes the UK government's spending review for imposing significant cuts on Scotland's budget, amounting to a 12.5% reduction by 2019-2020. He argues that these cuts are unnecessary and will impact essential services like schools, hospitals, and police. The UK government counters that Scotland will have more spending power next year and should focus on utilizing its new powers. Labour's Jackie Baillie calls for a long-term budget and criticizes the Scottish government's self-congratulatory tone, promising an alternative to austerity.

People with severe disabilities and their caregivers often face challenges when it comes to finding suitable toilet facilities outside their homes. While standard accessible toilets cater to many independent wheelchair users, those requiring two carers or a hoist for transfers are left with limited options. Campaigners advocate for mandatory installation of Changing Places toilets in large public spaces, which offer enhanced facilities for those with complex needs. The current voluntary guidelines have led to a lack of clarity and inconsistent implementation, impacting the psychological well-being of families. Making Changing Places compulsory in new builds, like shopping centres and stadiums, would ensure better accessibility and inclusivity, as demonstrated by successful installations at Arsenal Football Club and the Principality Stadium.

A group of Italian consumer organisations has filed a formal complaint against McDonald's with the European Commission, alleging that the company exploits its franchisees through excessive rents and fees. McDonald's defends its practices, stating that it shares risks and rewards with franchisees. The complaint is supported by international and European unions, who argue that McDonald's abuses its market power, harming franchisees, consumers, and workers. The European Commission will review the complaint and has the authority to launch an investigation. The consumer groups claim that McDonald's imposes long-term contracts and above-market rates, resulting in reduced consumer choice and higher prices in franchised stores compared to company-owned outlets. With franchisees operating 73% of McDonald's European restaurants, the outcome of this case could significantly impact the fast-food industry.

A social media campaign using the hashtag #prayforjosh has gained global attention to support 13-year-old Joshua Martin, who was diagnosed with cancer. The campaign started as a local initiative by Bangor Elim Church, where Josh's father works, and has since gone viral, with over 79,000 people reached and widespread support from around the world. The campaign's impact is further emphasised by the appearance of a billboard in Holywood, funded by an anonymous donor, showing the community's dedication to Josh's recovery.

The UK government's decision to close Brecon Barracks has sparked criticism from local Conservative MP Chris Davies, who highlights the site's rich military history and its significance to the community. The closure is part of a wider reorganisation of military buildings and regiments in Wales, which includes the creation of a specialist light infantry centre at St Athan. While Brecon Barracks' civilian and military staff are not expected to lose their jobs, the closure may impact the town's military tourism industry and contribute to existing unemployment concerns. The opposition Labour Party acknowledges the need for restructuring but raises concerns about the impact on local livelihoods.

The passage discusses the potential impact of Brexit on the UK fishing industry. It highlights the concerns of fishing communities, who fear being marginalized in the Brexit negotiations, as they strongly supported leaving the EU due to the perceived negative effects of the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP). The House of Lords report acknowledges these concerns and emphasizes the need to prioritize the industry, despite its small economic contribution. The report also mentions the complexities of shared fish stocks and the importance of maintaining market access for UK fish exports. While some in the fishing industry remain optimistic about post-Brexit opportunities, the report suggests that retaining certain elements of the CFP and ensuring scientific-based catch limits will be crucial. The UK government responds by emphasizing the goal of maximizing trade freedom while also improving fisheries management and sustainability.

Edward Snowden, a former CIA technical worker, leaked classified information to the Guardian, exposing the US government's extensive surveillance capabilities. The leaks revealed the National Security Agency's (NSA) access to various personal data, including chat logs, stored data, and social media activity. The US government confirmed requesting millions of phone records from Verizon, sparking debates about data protection and privacy. The NSA's director defended the surveillance, citing national security, but experts questioned its scope and effectiveness. The leaked documents also highlighted the involvement of major tech companies, allowing the NSA backdoor access to their servers. This global surveillance program, Prism, raised concerns about user privacy and the potential violation of data protection laws. The US Patriot Act and FISA Amendments Act provide legal grounds for US authorities to access non-American data stored in the US. The EU expressed concern, seeking more information, while the UK's involvement remains unclear. Privacy advocates argue that Prism enables the US government to access vast amounts of global data, raising serious privacy and legal issues.

Elon Musk, Peter Thiel, Infosys and Amazon Web Services have backed Open AI, a venture aiming to advance artificial intelligence (AI) research with a focus on benefiting humanity. While some experts warn of AI's potential threat to humanity, OpenAI emphasises its commitment to positive human impact and the safe and equitable distribution of AI technology. The organisation plans to operate without financial obligations, with only a small portion of its $1 billion funding to be spent in the near future.

Ben Parkinson, a former soldier, suffered a severe brain injury in Afghanistan in 2006, which affected his speech. Despite this, he has shown incredible determination and perseverance, regaining his speech and maintaining his personality and sense of humour. Ben's Olympic torch-carrying moment gained significant attention on Facebook, with thousands of friend requests, but he reached the platform's limit. His story and positive attitude have inspired many, leading to an outpouring of support and messages. Ben's family has been overwhelmed by the response, and he continues to raise funds for military charities, showcasing his resilience and dedication.

In 2011, the poverty rate in the US remained at 15%, affecting 46.2 million Americans, with a median income decline of 1.5%. The poverty threshold for a family of four was $23,021, and income inequality rose for the first time since 1993. Health insurance coverage improved slightly, but poverty levels reached a record high the previous year.

Jos Buttler, a 25-year-old cricketer, has extended his contract with Lancashire County Cricket Club until 2019. Known for his short-format expertise, Buttler holds the record for England's three fastest ODI centuries. Ashley Giles, the cricket director and head coach, praised Buttler's talent and impact on the team's success. After playing in the Indian Premier League, Buttler will rejoin Lancashire for a T20 Blast match against Durham.

The decommissioned Type 22 frigates HMS Cumberland, HMS Campbeltown, HMS Chatham, and HMS Cornwall are up for sale, with the government's Disposal Services Authority managing the process. No preservation proposals have been submitted, but interested parties are preparing their bids. The sale aims to assess the UK's ship recycling industry, while also considering the ships' potential for tourism attractions. The frigates, originally anti-submarine vessels, were versatile warships with advanced capabilities. The fate of the ships is expected to be decided in spring, with the Ministry of Defence seeking the best financial outcome.

Since 1987, Fiji has experienced significant political instability and international isolation due to racial tensions between indigenous Fijians and Indo-Fijians. A series of coups, starting in 1987 and continuing into the 2000s, led to economic setbacks and damage to the country's reputation. The coups resulted in a shift in the demographic balance, with indigenous Fijians now forming a small overall majority. The tensions culminated in a military takeover in 2006, leading to Fiji's suspension from the Commonwealth in 2009. After agreeing to hold free elections in 2014, Fiji's diplomatic ties with neighbouring countries were restored, and it was re-instated as a Commonwealth member. Despite economic challenges, Fiji's economy is diverse, relying on industries like sugar, tourism, mining, and services.

Syria's Deputy Foreign Minister, Faisal al-Mekdad, asserts the country's commitment to eliminating its chemical weapons, blaming delays on security issues and attacks by terrorist groups. Despite missing a deadline, Syria maintains it is cooperating with the UN and OPCW. The US and UK-based Syrian Observatory for Human Rights have criticised Syria's use of barrel bombs in Aleppo, resulting in numerous civilian casualties. Syria denies these claims and accuses the US of supporting terrorists. The Syrian government also refutes reports of rebels capturing Aleppo's central prison, which houses thousands of detainees in poor conditions. The OPCW acknowledges security concerns have slowed the chemical weapons destruction process.

The Booker Prize, in its 46th year, has expanded its eligibility to all English-language authors. The favourite to win is The Lives of Others by Mukherjee, set in 1960s Calcutta. The shortlist includes former winner Howard Jacobson, Ali Smith, Joshua Ferris, Karen Joy Fowler, and Richard Flanagan. Fowler's We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves is the bestseller among the nominees. The winner will be revealed in London, with the shortlisted authors receiving a monetary prize and a special edition of their book.

A celebrity, referred to as PJS, is fighting to keep his identity private regarding allegations of extramarital activities. The Supreme Court will hear arguments to decide if an appeal should be granted, maintaining an interim injunction until the hearing's conclusion. The Court of Appeal previously allowed the publication of the story, as details were already widespread, despite PJS's legal efforts to protect his privacy.

Fosse Park, a retail park acquired for ÃÂ£345.5 million, is undergoing plans for improvement. The new owners aim to enhance parking, reduce traffic congestion, and revitalise the site's appearance. The park's strategic location at the gateway to the city makes it an important investment for the new owners, who are working with the local council to address planning matters. The goal is to create a more aesthetically pleasing entrance to the city and upgrade the overall visitor experience.

The live-action remake of "Beauty and the Beast" has sparked debate in Malaysia due to a "gay moment" involving the character LeFou. Despite the film receiving approval with minor edits, its release has been delayed for further review, causing controversy among netizens who criticize the decision as unnecessary censorship. The film's director has openly discussed the gay subplot, which explores LeFou's complex feelings for Gaston.

Landlords in Southampton are required to obtain a licence for Houses of Multiple Occupation (HMO) with more than three unrelated tenants, but many avoid it due to the high cost. This is despite the risk of substantial fines. There are an estimated 1,500 unlicensed HMOs in the city, and tenants often face issues like eviction fears and poorly maintained properties. Nationally, mandatory HMO licensing targets larger properties with five or more unrelated occupants. Southampton's licensing scheme covers specific areas, and while most landlords comply, a few have faced prosecution for non-compliance.

Enda Kenny and MicheÃ¡l Martin aim to prevent a second election, with Martin's Fianna FÃ¡il party offering support for a minority government. Water charges are a significant obstacle to an agreement, with Fianna FÃ¡il advocating for their removal and Fine Gael supporting their implementation. The recent election resulted in a hung parliament, with Fine Gael holding 50 seats, Fianna FÃ¡il 44, Sinn FÃ©in 23, and Labour seven, leaving no party with a majority and no Taoiseach elected.

The Sorrento ferry caught fire while sailing to Valencia, leading to a full evacuation of passengers and crew. The blaze started on a car deck, causing injuries to at least three people. Rescued individuals were transferred to another ferry and are en route to Palma de Mallorca. The ship's fate is uncertain, as it may sink due to the fire's severity.

The Electoral Commission reported that 38 MPs raised concerns about potential double voting, a criminal offence, with students among those suspected. The issue is attributed to disconnected electoral registers and the lack of a direct link between these registers and the online registration service. This disconnection led to a high number of duplicate applications, estimated between 30% and 70% in various areas, causing administrative and financial strain. The Commission suggested implementing a verification function and providing clearer information on registration sites. Despite efforts to inform people about their registration status, many still submitted multiple applications due to the ease of the online process. While evidence of double voting is lacking, the Commission takes the matter seriously and encourages reporting to the police. The Commission also highlighted the need to cross-check entries across registers and proposed that individuals registered in two seats should pre-select their voting constituency for general elections. Labour's Cat Smith emphasized the importance of not deterring young voters and students from registering, suggesting that a blanket ban on dual registration could disadvantage those with multiple residences for work or study.

Lawrence Phillips, a former NFL player, is believed to have committed suicide while in prison. Phillips, a star player in college, had a promising NFL career until 1999, but was known for his legal troubles. He was convicted of assault on multiple occasions and was serving a long prison sentence. The day before his apparent suicide, a judge ruled that Phillips would stand trial for the death of his cellmate.

A Swaledale ram named Private Derby XXX, serving as a mascot for the Mercian Regiment, was promoted to lance corporal for his good behaviour. This ram is the 30th in a lineage of mascot rams dating back to the 19th century. He joined the regiment in 2014 and has participated in various ceremonial duties, including meeting Prince William.

Liverpool FC secured a dramatic 4-3 victory over Borussia Dortmund in the Europa League, advancing to the semi-finals. The game was filled with emotion, drama, and brilliant football, with Liverpool's comeback mirroring their famous 2005 Champions League Final triumph. Jurgen Klopp's influence was evident as his team refused to give up, turning doubters into believers. The match was a showcase of Liverpool's attacking prowess, but defensive vulnerabilities remain. Klopp's impact on the club's identity was clear, and the win has increased belief in the team's ability to achieve success in the Europa League and secure a Champions League spot.

The EU Negotiation Joint Ministerial Committee met in London to discuss Brexit negotiations. UK government representative, Mr Davis, assured Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland of regular updates and proposed monthly meetings to facilitate a two-way information exchange. He acknowledged differing viewpoints but emphasized a constructive atmosphere. Mr Russell, representing Scotland, welcomed the inclusion of the Scottish government but criticized the UK government's lack of transparency regarding its strategic intentions, especially concerning EU market access. He stressed the importance of single market membership for Scotland's economy. The UK government awaits the Supreme Court's ruling on Article 50, while the Scottish government plans to oppose the UK government during the appeal.

A flock of 13 cloned sheep, including four clones from the same adult ewe as Dolly (the first cloned mammal), are undergoing thorough physical examinations by veterinary surgeon Dr. Sandra Corr. These sheep are part of a study led by Professor Kevin Sinclair to investigate if cloned animals age normally and if they are as healthy as non-cloned animals. The research aims to address concerns about the cloning process potentially transferring "age-memory" and causing premature aging. The original Dolly died at six-and-a-half years old due to a virus and osteoarthritis, prompting the study to determine if her early death was cloning-related. The sheep are being closely monitored for various age-related diseases, and the study's results will have significant implications for the future of cloning.

John Gosden's Shutter Speed won the Musidora Stakes, remaining unbeaten and securing a spot in the French Oaks at Chantilly. Despite soft ground conditions, she beat Vintage Folly by a length and three-quarters. Gosden also trains top contenders Enable and Coronet for the longer Epsom Oaks. Tasleet won the Duke of York Stakes, while Gosden's colt Cracksman's participation in the Dante Stakes is uncertain due to ground concerns.

The British pound experienced volatility in the lead-up to the EU referendum vote, initially slipping against the dollar and euro but then recovering and falling again. The Leave campaign attributed this to normal fluctuations, while analysts suggested that uncertainty and the possibility of a Brexit were causing market jitters. Polls indicated a tight race, increasing investors' uncertainty and impacting the pound's value. Hedge funds were short-selling sterling, and the markets were on high alert for a potential Brexit. The economic implications of a potential Brexit were also affecting global markets, with Asian stocks falling and the FTSE 100 showing a decline.

The Iron, currently sixth in the National League, narrowly missed the play-off spots by one point. Despite a tough journey and an early goal conceded, the team's manager, Cowley, remained optimistic after a loss to Barrow. He acknowledged the team's remarkable progress so far, considering their part-time status, and embraced the challenge ahead, determined to enjoy the experience.

A proposed change in Northern Ireland's planning system will give local councils and politicians more power over planning decisions, including accepting or rejecting developments. This move is seen as an opportunity for local control and community development by some, like Michael Corr, who believes it can democratise planning. However, concerns have been raised about potential discrimination, favouritism, and the need for transparency, especially regarding political donations and relationships with developers. The environmental group Friends of the Earth calls for strict conduct codes and transparency measures to ensure fairness. The historical context of the 1960s housing discrimination and the Civil Rights movement adds to these concerns, with James Orr warning against a repeat of past issues. Some politicians oppose the change due to security concerns for donors, while others downplay the impact of donation limits. The decision to implement these changes and address transparency issues rests with the Northern Ireland Secretary.

A one-year-old cat named Teenie was shot three times with an airgun, resulting in the amputation of her left back leg. The cat's owner, Sarah Nisbett, found her injured and expressed concern about the danger of such weapons in a residential area with children. The Scottish SPCA and Teenie's owners are seeking information to find the person responsible, emphasizing the need for urgent action by the Scottish government to license airguns. Despite a consultation on licensing, the majority of respondents opposed the plan, calling it "draconian" and "heavy-handed." The proposed licensing scheme aims to ensure that only those with a legitimate reason can own air guns and to aid police in tracing irresponsible use.

Christian Benteke has joined Liverpool from Aston Villa for an undisclosed fee, becoming the club's second most expensive signing. The Belgian international striker, known for his physical presence and goal-scoring ability, is expected to bolster Liverpool's attack after a disappointing season. Benteke's arrival follows the signings of Danny Ings, Roberto Firmino, and the return of Divock Origi, as Liverpool aim to improve their goal-scoring record and challenge for trophies.

A study examining the use of tablet devices in schools found that while there is no conclusive evidence of academic improvement, tablets are becoming increasingly prevalent in classrooms. The study, which surveyed a diverse range of schools, revealed that tablets are used in some capacity in the majority of primary and secondary schools, with a growing trend towards more intensive use. Researchers noted that head teachers reported positive impacts, particularly in engaging disinterested pupils and involving families. The study highlights the integration of online technology into the daily lives of young people, with many pupils describing themselves as internet "addicts" and using devices in bed for social media. Despite the lack of definitive proof linking tablets to improved results, educators argue that technology in schools mirrors students' home lives and future workplaces, fostering a sense of empowerment and trust.

The exhibition "Growing Up in the City" at the Museum of Liverpool showcases 25 photographs that offer a glimpse into the lives of children from the 1880s to the 1990s. These images not only capture the innocence of childhood but also provide a social commentary on Liverpool's history. The photographs depict various aspects of childhood, from fancy dress balls to the reality of child labour. Curated by Kay Jones, the exhibition aims to evoke emotions and memories, highlighting both the joys and hardships of growing up in the city.

Anderson, a 27-year-old centre-back, has left Barrow to join a rival National League club, potentially facing his former team on February 18th. Meanwhile, 21-year-old striker Keating, with experience in Ireland, joins the Gulls, who are seeking reinforcement as they sit just above the relegation zone with recent poor form.

Bolivia has passed a new law that allows 12-year-olds to work with parental consent, reflecting the country's unique needs and poverty levels. The legislation also imposes stricter penalties for violence against children, including a 30-year sentence for child homicide. This law aims to address the reality of child labour in Bolivia, where over 500,000 children already work to support their families. While it diverges from international conventions, the government believes it is a practical approach to eradicating extreme poverty. The International Labour Organisation is reviewing the law to determine its compliance with child labour regulations.

Rosie O'Donnell, a 50-year-old celebrity, shared her experience of a heart attack on her blog. She recognised her symptoms, which included nausea and aches, and took aspirin. The next day, a cardiologist treated her for a severely blocked artery. O'Donnell urged women to be aware of heart attack symptoms and to seek emergency help.

A 16-year-old boy named Che Labastide-Wellington was stabbed and killed at a party in Kenton, London. He was not involved in an initial fight with a group of youths but was later targeted and stabbed in an alleyway. A 16-year-old boy was also stabbed and hospitalised, while a 21-year-old man and two teenage boys were arrested on suspicion of murder. The police are appealing for witnesses who were near the alleyway at the time of the stabbing.

A new approach to cancer diagnosis and treatment has been implemented in Denmark, aiming to improve survival rates and address long waiting times. This system involves three routes: fast-tracking patients with obvious symptoms, establishing diagnosis centres for complex cases, and creating "yes-no" centres for minor symptoms. The changes have resulted in better organisation, improved survival rates, and reduced waiting times without overwhelming the healthcare system. Wales, with a similar healthcare system, can learn from Denmark's success in breaking down barriers between GPs and specialists, potentially catching up with the best in Europe.

The UK government has disbanded the OFT, and Powys has been awarded the contract to deliver a new service in its place. This service will issue warning and banning orders against agents acting dishonestly or breaking estate agent laws. Complaints will still be made to local authority trading standards departments, who will refer cases to Powys if they believe the Estate Agents Act has been breached. Powys will receive Â£170,000 annually for this work, and James Munro from Powys Council hopes this will lead to further contracts and external work.

The NHS Employers organization has approved a plan to expand the roles of nurses and other healthcare staff, addressing staff shortages and changing care needs. A Nuffield Trust review highlighted examples of nurses taking on additional responsibilities, such as filling in for doctors and pharmacists. While this approach offers opportunities to improve patient care and staff roles, unions and medical associations caution against compromising doctor training and expertise. The plan aims to address gaps in junior doctor rotas and the rising patient numbers in GP practices, but concerns about funding for training and maintaining high-quality care standards have been raised.

A road closure on the A36 Lower Bristol Road in Bath, caused by a crash, led to significant disruptions during the morning rush hour. The closure lasted until 14:00 GMT, affecting commuters and bus services. First, the bus company, worked to restore services, aiming for a full resumption by the evening commute. Investigations are ongoing to determine the cause of the collision.

The Natural Resources Wales (NRW) estimated that the proposed Swansea tidal lagoon project would result in significant fish mortality, with 21% of salmon and 25% of sea trout dying annually during their migration. Tidal Lagoon Power (TLP), the project developer, disputed these claims, stating that NRW's figures lacked scientific basis and that their own computer modelling estimated a much lower impact, with a worst-case scenario of 2% mortality for all fish species. TLP accused NRW of refusing to share its methodology, while NRW defended its assessment, stating that it was based on extensive evidence and discussions with the developer, and had been reviewed by independent experts. The Â£1.3 billion project is seen as a test for larger versions along the coast, and the UK government is reviewing its viability. The Welsh Government supports the scheme but awaits clarity from the UK government.

The Northern Ireland government announced the creation of a new marketing body for the agri-food industry, aiming to boost economic growth and provide strategic direction. The industry employs almost 100,000 people and the new body, similar to Scotland Food and Drink, will enhance marketing efforts. Agriculture Minister Michelle O'Neill welcomed the initiative but noted potential implications for existing organisations, including her department.

The Woodland Trust is organising a tree-planting event at Brackfield Wood in the Faughan Valley, inviting the public to participate. The project aims to commemorate the millions of lives lost during WW1 by planting millions of native UK trees across four new woods in the UK. Brackfield Wood will see 40,000 trees planted, honouring the Irish lives lost in the war. The event encourages local involvement, offering a chance to contribute to a growing memorial and support wildlife conservation. The charity provides saplings and advises volunteers on appropriate footwear, with the event taking place just outside Derry city.

Hilary's novel, Someone Else's Skin, won the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award, praised for its powerful storytelling and atmospheric writing. The book is the first in a series featuring Det Insp Marnie Rome, tackling domestic violence and honour crime. The award ceremony, held in Harrogate, also recognised US author Sara Paretsky for her outstanding contribution to crime fiction with her iconic character, VI Warshawski, a groundbreaking female investigator. Paretsky's work inspired a movie and radio adaptation, and she founded Sisters In Crime to support female crime writers globally.

Mitch Santner, a left-arm batsman and spinner, will rejoin the Worcestershire Rapids after a previous stint in 2016, where he unfortunately suffered a finger injury. The team's director of cricket, Steve Rhodes, acknowledges Santner's potential impact and their disappointment in his early departure last season. Santner aims to make a comeback and contribute to the team's success in the upcoming season.

Barry Pring, a 47-year-old millionaire, was killed by a speeding car in Kiev in 2008 while trying to hail a taxi. His wife, Ganna Ziuzina (Anna), was suspected of orchestrating his death to inherit his wealth. The coroner ruled it an unlawful killing, and witnesses described it as a deliberate act. Ms. Ziuzina, who was much younger than her husband, tried to claim his assets quickly after his death. The couple met online and had a brief engagement before marrying. Mr. Pring's family believes it was a staged hit-and-run, and they suspect Ms. Ziuzina's involvement due to her questionable behaviour and financial motives. The Ukrainian police initially closed the case but later reopened it as a murder inquiry, which remains active but not actively pursued.

A young boy from Merseyside, Charlie, requires urgent medical treatment in Seattle, USA, for a life-threatening illness. After a failed transplant and with no options left in the UK, Charlie's family was desperate for a solution. An anonymous donor has generously offered to fund Charlie's treatment at Seattle Children's Hospital, covering the cost of experimental T-Cell Therapy. The family is overwhelmed by this act of kindness and is awaiting confirmation of the treatment date.

Apple has introduced a two-factor authentication system to enhance security for iCloud users, addressing concerns about third-party software being used to steal celebrity photos. This new measure requires an extra step during login, involving a four-digit code sent to a trusted device or via Apple's Find My iPhone app. While the feature was previously available, it now applies to the backup service, preventing unauthorised access to data even with a stolen password. Apple's changes have rendered Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker ineffective, according to its owner, Vladimir Katalov. However, concerns remain about the complexity of the recovery key and the potential risks if it is lost or stolen. Security experts advocate for making two-factor authentication the default setting, with Apple planning to encourage its use more aggressively.

A potential deal is in the works where Mark Wright might purchase a 20% stake in Billericay Town FC, but specific details are yet to be disclosed. This news comes after the club's recent takeover by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who has shown a willingness to invest significantly. Billericay Town FC is currently mid-table in their league, and they recently signed former England player Paul Konchesky. Mark Wright, a former reality TV star, has a background in non-league football.

Mr Ashley, owner of Sports Direct and Newcastle United Football Club, has been requested to provide evidence regarding the treatment of his company's workers and their adherence to minimum wage regulations. This follows an investigation by the BBC and an invitation from the BIS select committee, chaired by Hartlepool MP Iain Wright, to discuss the matter. Mr Ashley has been urged to respond by March 21st, with the committee threatening further action if he fails to cooperate.

A group of Russian opposition politicians, led by Ilya Yashin, have compiled a report titled "Putin. War," which accuses President Vladimir Putin of orchestrating the conflict in Ukraine for his personal gain. The report gathers information from various media sources and presents evidence of Russian military involvement, including soldier testimonies, equipment documentation, and financial expenditures. The opposition aims to expose Putin's role in the war, which they believe he engineered to increase his popularity. However, publishing and distributing such sensitive material is challenging, and the report's impact remains uncertain, especially given the limited public reaction to similar previous works.

Craig Nelson, a 34-year-old man from Rotherham, was found deceased at the Woodhead Tunnels in Derbyshire on Monday morning. A post-mortem examination determined the cause of death to be head injuries. Two individuals, a 41-year-old man and a 23-year-old woman, were arrested in Sheffield by South Yorkshire Police and are currently in custody.

The passage discusses the tension between the Welsh government and the UK government regarding the Article 50 letter and the Brexit negotiations. Carwyn Jones, the First Minister of Wales, expressed frustration over not being consulted on the letter's content, despite discussions with the Prime Minister, Theresa May. Jones criticized the lack of respect shown to the devolved administrations, while Welsh Secretary Alun Cairns defended the UK government's actions, stating that they are acting in the interests of the whole UK. The passage also mentions the UK government's intention to consult on the return of powers to Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland, but questions remain about which specific powers will be devolved and whether funding will accompany them. The issue of EU funding in Wales and its potential transfer to Westminster is also raised, with some uncertainty surrounding the future of these powers.

Two cars were damaged in an incident in Newry on Friday night, where police officers and the community were attacked. The police urged parents to be aware of their children's whereabouts and activities.

Mr Charney, the founder of American Apparel, was removed from the company due to employee complaints and allegations of misconduct, including sexual harassment and misuse of funds. The board stated they do not intend to rehire him, citing privacy invasion and defamation. Mr Charney's lawyer denied the accusations and accused the company of extortion. Court documents reveal inappropriate emails and racial taunts by Mr Charney, supporting the company's claims. The board believes rehiring him would pose a significant risk. Recently, a restraining order was issued against Mr Charney, preventing him from making negative statements about the company and attempting to remove board members.

The British basketball team will play Greece at the Copper Box in London, with the game available to watch on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website and app. This is a chance for GB to avenge their recent defeat to Greece, who will be missing three players from their previous encounter. The match is a crucial warm-up for the British team ahead of FIBA EuroBasket 2017, which begins in September in Istanbul, Turkey.

The passage recounts the author's experience covering the launch of the iPhone, a product that was initially met with scepticism but has since proven to be a revolutionary technology. The iPhone's user-friendly interface made smartphones accessible to the masses, transforming how people communicate, access information, and engage in various activities like photography. The author reflects on the significance of witnessing this pivotal moment in technological history, despite initial reservations about the hype.

The RSPCA is investigating a series of cat poisonings in Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire, where multiple cats, including Meereen, have died after ingesting antifreeze. It is unclear if the poisonings are accidental or intentional, but the RSPCA is urging residents to store pesticides and chemicals safely, especially during the season when antifreeze is commonly used in vehicles.

The passage discusses the absence of public demonstrations in Athens, Greece, despite the Syriza government's impending agreement on austerity measures and economic liberalisation. This is surprising given the impending tax increases, pension cuts, and other potentially harmful economic reforms. The author speculates that the public may be waiting for the details of the third bailout agreement, worth Ã¢âÂ¬86bn, which is expected to be revealed later in the week.
